Selective oxidation of CO in the presence of H2, CO2 and H2O, on different zeolite-supported Pt catalysts V. Sebastian S. Irusta R. Mallada J. Santamaría ⁎ Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering and Nanoscience Institute of Aragón, University of Zaragoza, Zaragoza, Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The selective oxidation of CO has been studied over different Pt/zeolite catalysts. The effect of H2O and CO2 in the reactor depended on the specific catalyst, with the stronger influence for Pt–ETS-10:CO2 strongly inhibited its activity and also caused a large decrease in its selectivity but these effects were completely reversed upon the introduction of water. The selective oxidation of CO in the presence of H2O and CO2 has been studied on Pt supported on different zeolitic materials (MOR, ZSM-5, FAU and ETS-10) using a range of operating conditions and a variety of characterization techniques. The behavior of the Pt–ETS-10 and Pt–FAU catalysts has been investigated in more depth and the results obtained have been compared and related to the different characteristics of the supports. The best results in the presence of H2O and CO2 were obtained with Pt–FAU catalysts, showing stable catalytic activity and complete conversion of CO (λ =2) at 439K. Keywords CO SELOX Selective oxidation Microporous materials ETS-10 Faujasite Platinum Fuel cells 1 Introduction The use of proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) systems for stationary and mobile applications has gained importance over the last few years [1,2]. On-board hydrogen production by reforming liquid hydrocarbons continues to be researched as an attractive alternative to achieve an acceptable driving range, and the potential market for power generation in residential applications has excellent growth prospects in many countries. All primary fuel processing reactions in the reformer, produce substantial amounts of carbon monoxide, whose strong chemisorption would cause poisoning of the platinum-based electrode. This makes the product gas unsuitable for direct feeding to PEM fuel cells, even after decreasing the CO concentration in a subsequent water gas shift reactor. Typical reformate gas compositions at the exit of the water gas shift reactor include 15–20vol.% CO2, 0.5–2vol.% CO and about 15–25vol.% H2O [3]. The CO concentration must be reduced to values below 10ppm before the stream enters the PEM fuel cell. Although work on the design of novel anode CO-resistant catalysts is in progress [4], reducing the CO concentration to tolerable levels by means of a low-temperature selective CO oxidation still seems to be the most promising and lowest cost approach among all the methods available [5]. The main reactions to be considered are the selective oxidation of carbon monoxide (SELOX, Eq. (1)), which is the desired reaction and several side reactions (Eqs. (2)–(5), [6]). (1) CO + 1 2 O 2 ⇒ C O 2 , Δ H 298 K = − 284 kJ/mol (2) H 2 + 1 2 O 2 ⇒ H 2 O, Δ H 298 K = − 242 kJ/mol (3) C O 2 + H 2 ⇔ CO + H 2 O, Δ H 298 K = 41 kJ/mol (4) CO + 3 H 2 ⇔ C H 4 + H 2 O, Δ H 298 K = − 206 kJ/mol (5) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ⇔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O, Δ H 298 K = − 165 kJ/mol The classical catalysts for the selective oxidation of CO include noble metals (Pd, Ru, Rh, Pt), generally supported on alumina. Pt-group-metals catalysts exhibit good activity, with 100% CO conversion and 30–50% oxygen-based selectivity (i.e., considering reactions (1) and (2)) in the temperature range of 400–573K. Catalytic activity in the order: Ru>Rh>Pt>Pd has been reported [7]. The main efforts to improve the performance of these oxidation catalysts include the use of additional metals or oxides in order to increase the catalytic activity by promoting oxidation. This is the case of Fe [8–10], and of many research works using CeO2 as a support, and of CuO–CeO2 catalysts [6,11,12]. Total conversion of CO could be achieved at temperatures in the range 373–420K with selectivities of 50–70% in the case of Fe catalysts, while higher temperatures, around 473K were needed with the copper–ceria catalysts. A recent work [13], reviews the different catalysts used for the SELOX reaction and the alternatives for CO removal in H2-rich conditions, including the use of membranes and of CO methanation processes. Overall, catalysts based on supported Ru and Pt seem to be the most promising in terms of activity under realistic conditions, long term stability and operating temperature window. Supported gold catalysts have been reported to be quite active for the PROX especially at low-temperatures, however, the selectivity for CO oxidation over H2 oxidation decreased rapidly with increasing reaction temperature. It is important to note that in most of the published investigations on the SELOX reaction, the feed mixture only includes CO and H2. This means that the effect of CO2 and H2O, always present in real reformate streams, is neglected. This is a risky assumption, since specific effects not only exist, but seem to depend strongly on the system investigated. Thus for instance, in the case of gold, a clear decrease of activity was reported in the presence of CO2 [14]. Au catalysts are generally more active and more selective than Pt, however, they may suffer deactivation due to sintering during reaction [15]. In contrast, a beneficial effect of H2O, with increase of activity without change of selectivity was found [16] for Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, and a weak influence (mild decrease of the SELOX reaction rate) was reported for CO2 and H2O on CuO/CeO2 catalysts [17]. The use of zeolites as a support for Pt catalysts in the SELOX reaction has been intensely studied by the group of Watanabe [9,18–23], generally with satisfactory results. Thus, they found a high activity for Pt on zeolite A, and a high Pt dispersion and stabilization of metal nano-crystallites when the zeolite was ZSM-5 or mordenite [21], resulting in a significant improvement of CO conversion and selectivity. The best results were obtained with a Pt–Fe/mordenite catalyst: complete CO conversion was obtained at 423K in a synthetic gas mixture containing 1% CO, 1% O2, 20% CO2 and 20% H2O in H2 with no noticeable degradation of performance for 24h. Pt–zeolite A and Rh-based catalysts supported on zeolite A, were studied by the group of Spechia et al. [2,24], and for the case of Rh, they were able to reduce CO concentration below 10ppm at temperatures below 393K. This work describes the development of Pt-based catalysts for selective CO oxidation, using several zeolitic supports (MOR, ZSM-5, FAU and ETS-10). These supports have different properties: pore diameter and structure, Si/Al ratio and, for the case of ETS-10, inclusion of Ti in the structure. These differences will give rise to variations in the distribution of Pt and will determine the accesibility of the reactants to the active sites. Furthermore the acidic or basic nature of the support will influence the interaction with the different components in the reaction mixture. To our knowledge, this is the first time that catalysts consisting of Pt supported on zeolite Y and on ETS-10 have been used for the SELOX reaction. Also, unlike many of the previous works, in this investigation special attention was paid to the effect of water and CO2 in these two catalysts, and their stability was also tested in longer duration experiments. Finally, this work is part of an ongoing research whose final objective is the development of microreactors with Pt/zeolite catalysts for the SELOX reaction. Because of the limitations of catalytic load inherent to microreactors, we have aimed for a high Pt load per unit mass and prepared catalysts with Pt concentrations (up to 7.3wt.%) well above the usual values in the literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalyst supports were first synthesised by seeded (secondary) hydrothermal synthesis in the liquid phase; then Pt was introduced in the microporous structure by conventional ion-exchange. The microporous materials used were alumino-silicates (MFI, MOR and FAU) and titanosilicates (ETS-10) and their synthesis has been described in previous works for MOR, FAU and ETS-10 [25], and for MFI [26], respectively. Table 1 shows a summary of the sol compositions and the synthesis conditions employed for the different materials. The Na+ in the ion-exchange positions was replaced by the existing Pt2+ ions in a [Pt(NH3)4](NO3)2 solution. To this end, the solid was immersed in the solution under slow agitation for 24h, following procedures similar to those described in the literature [9,19]. The temperature for the ion-exchange was 333K in the case of FAU and MOR and 298K for MFI and ETS-10. Finally the solution was filtered and the solid was washed with abundant deionized water, until the conductivity of the liquid in contact with the solid was lower than 20μS, then dried overnight at 348K. The Pt dispersion on the catalyst depends strongly on the activation conditions used, mainly the heating rate and gas atmosphere [27]. In this work the catalysts were calcined in air for 3h at 623K with a heating rate of 0.2K/min, followed by a conditioning period under 10% H2 for 3h at the same temperature, then cooled down under N2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization A battery of techniques was used to characterize the catalyst. The crystallinity, purity and structure were studied by X-ray diffraction, XRD (Rygaku/Max System RU 300). Inductive coupled plasma, ICP (Perkin Elmer P-40) was used for bulk chemical analysis, while the surface composition was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with an Axis Ultra DLD (Kratos Tech.). In this case, the samples were mounted on a sample rod placed in the pretreatment chamber of the spectrometer and evacuated at room temperature. The spectra were excited by the monochromatized Al Kα source (1486.6eV) run at 15kV and 10mA. Analyzes of the peaks were performed with the CasaXPS software, using a weighted sum of Lorentzian and Gaussian components curves after background subtraction. In order to analyze the contribution of the two elements in the Al 2p and Pt 4f peaks, it was assumed that (i) the BE and FWHM of the Al 2p peak were the same as in the unloaded zeolite and (ii) the spin–orbit splitting for Pt was fixed to 3.35eV and the Pt 4f5/2/Pt 4f7/2 intensity ratio was kept constant (0.75) [28]. In order to take into account the metallic Pt 4f asymmetric profile a Voigt-like function was used. FWHM values for the metallic components were kept between 1.07 and 1.21eV. The binding energies were referenced to the internal standard C 1s (284.9eV). The specific surface area, BET method, and pore volume was measured by nitrogen adsorption at 77K in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020, samples were outgassed at 26.7Pa and 623K for 6h. The BET equation was limited to the pressure range where the term Q(P 0 − P) continuously increases with P/P 0 [29]. Temperature-programmed reduction experiments were performed with a heating rate of 5K/min under a 5%:95%(v/v) H2:Ar stream. Pt dispersion was determined by H2 chemisorption. Volumetric adsorption experiments were performed at 298K in a vacuum equipment. The catalysts were previously reduced in H2 flow at 673K and then evacuated at 773K prior to the chemisorption experiments. The hydrogen consumption was determined by the double isotherm method. A stoichiometry of 1:1 H:Pt was assumed to calculate Pt dispersion from the chemisorbed hydrogen. 2.3 Activity tests The catalytic activity was measured in a packed bed reactor consisting of a quartz tube of 10mm diameter. The reactor was loaded with 100mg of catalyst and 200mg of quartz, used as a diluent. The WHSV was 2mlmin−1 mg−1 and in order to study the effects of CO2 and H2O four different feed streams were used, see Table 2 . The oxygen concentration in the feed is expressed in terms of λ (see Eq. (6)), a parameter that measures the excess of oxygen over the stoichiometric amount needed to oxidise all the CO in the feed (λ =1 would introduce exactly the amount of oxygen required to convert the CO to CO2); however, values of λ >1 are necessary to convert 100% of CO, since the catalyst is not totally selective, and part of the oxygen is consumed in H2 conversion. (6) λ = 2 × P O 2 F e e d P CO F e e d The reaction temperature was measured by a thermocouple located at the center of the catalyst bed. Temperature measurements at other bed positions indicated that the temperature deviations with respect to the temperature in this point were ±3K. The gas compositions at the inlet and outlet were measured by on-line gas chromatography (Varian MicroGC-4900, equipped with thermal conductivity detectors and two columns, CP740148 MS5A and CP740150 PPQ), allowing analysis of H2, O2, CO, CH4, H2O and CO2, respectively. The maximum error of the mass balance closures for carbon and oxygen was 2.1%. CH4 was not detected in any of the experiments carried out, meaning that the extension of reaction (4) was negligible under the conditions employed. The CO conversion values have been calculated from Eq. (7). The oxygen conversion and the selectivity of the SELOX reaction were calculated according to Eqs. (8) and (9), respectively. The turnover frequency, TOF, was calculated using Eq. (10). In these equations F i corresponds to the molar flux of component i. (7) CO conversion ( % ) = F CO F e e d − F CO O u t l e t F CO F e e d × 100 (8) O 2 conversion ( % ) = F O 2 F e e d − F O 2 O u t l e t F O 2 F e e d × 100 (9) Selectivity ( % ) = 0.5 × ( F CO F e e d − F CO O u t l e t ) ( F O 2 F e e d − F O 2 O u t l e t ) × 100 (10) TOF m o l C O 2 min · m o l Pt e f f i c i e n t = F CO F e e d − F CO O u t l e t m o l Pt × % d i s p e r s i o n Finally the activities of the different catalysts were also compared by considering the T 100 and T 50 values, defined as the temperatures at which 100% and 50% CO conversions were reached, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of microporous supports and catalysts A summary of the catalysts prepared and their properties, Pt content, specific surface area and Pt dispersion is presented in Table 3 . The lowest Pt content corresponds to ZSM-5 (Pt–MFI100) with a Si/Al ratio equal to 100. This catalyst composition had the highest Si/Al ratio (Table 1) and therefore the lowest concentration of exchange positions. The low Pt dispersion obtained for this catalyst can also be explained in part as a consequence of the pretreatment used for the chemisorption measurements, involving temperatures of 673K under hydrogen, followed by evacuation at 773K. In fact, Kotobuki et al. [30] found that treating Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts at 773K under air resulted in the formation of large Pt particles outside the ZSM-5 structure. For the Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst, a reduction in the pore volume and surface area was not observed after the ion-exchange procedure. In contrast, a significant reduction of the BET specific surface area and pore volume was observed as a consequence of the higher Pt loading for the other Pt/zeolite catalysts. This reduction is relatively less important in the case of zeolite Y (FAU), whose channel diameter (7.4×7.4Å) is larger than that of MOR and ETS-10 (6.5×7.0Å and 2.6×5.7Å and 4.9×7.6Å, respectively). The highest values for Pt dispersion were obtained on the FAU support (Table 3), which is also the material with the highest Al/Si ratio (Table 4 ). The high dispersion of Pt on the FAU zeolite may also be aided by a somewhat lower Pt load (6.3% vs. 7.3%) and by the larger channels of this zeolite, meaning that the precursor Pt(NH3)4 can penetrate the zeolite pore network and decompose without diffusing out of the pores [22]. This high dispersion could also be related to the fact that the hydrogen chemisorption capacity of Pt is directly influenced by the ionicity of the support oxygen and/or some spill-over favored by the Pt [31] The materials obtained by hydrothermal synthesis were pure, crystalline phases. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the prepared catalysts, after the activation procedure. In the case of Pt–MOR, Pt–FAU and Pt–MFI100 the Pt reflexion at 39.7° is not observed, meaning that Pt aggregates are not present in significant concentration or, if they are present, their size is small enough to avoid detection by XRD. Only for the case of Pt–ETS-10, Pt aggregates outside the microporous structure are evident, in accordance with the low Pt dispersion observed and the low pore volume of this zeolite (Table 3). The formation of these aggregates can be related to the higher mobility of the Pt atoms during the activation procedure due to a weaker interaction with the microporous structure. The size of these aggregates according to the Scherrer equation, was approximately 9.1nm. However, given the conditions used in this work (large Pt loads, calcination treatments during catalyst preparation, catalysts of subnanometric pore size), the presence of a significant proportion of Pt as clusters outside the zeolite framework structure is to be expected. As an example, Fig. 2 shows a TEM view of the Pt/MOR catalyst (with an intermediate value of Pt dispersion, Table 3). As can be seen, Pt clusters with a size around 2nm are clearly present, homogeneously dispersed throughout the catalyst. The relative positions of the reduction peaks in the TPR diagram can in principle be used to grade the interaction between the metal and the microporous structure, with lower reduction temperatures indicating a facile reduction of the Pt species, and therefore a weaker metal–support interaction or a high accessibility of the site or both. However, the reduction temperatures on Pt/zeolite catalysts must be interpreted with caution as they also depend on a series of factors such as the preparation technique, calcination temperature and type of support. In the literature, reduction peaks for platinum-containing zeolites catalysts have been reported in a very wide temperature range, between 300 and 1073K [27,32–36]. This is also observed in Fig. 3 where the TPR profiles of the different catalysts are presented. In the case of Pt/ZSM-5 the position of the different ion-exchange positions (α, β, δ) approximately corresponds to those observed by other authors after ion-exchange of Co2+ [37]. On the other hand, the appearance of Pt outside the microporous structure is usually indicated by the presence of reduction peaks at ambient or even sub-ambient temperatures [29], a feature that was not observed in this case for any of the catalysts, not even for Pt–ETS-10, in spite of the presence of extraframework clusters detected by XRD. It is also worth noting that all of the Pt catalysts on the different supports, ETS-10 included, present a considerable proportion of Pt that is only reduced at high temperatures (750K and higher), indicating Pt in ion-exchange positions [36]. The highest reduction temperatures were observed for Pt–MOR and Pt–FAU, in both cases the main reduction peak is at 850K or higher, with a shoulder above 900K in the case of Pt–FAU. The chemical state of elements and their relative proportions were determined by XPS, the results are presented in Table 4 and Fig. 4 . The binding energies of Si 2p, Al 2p, Na 1s, O 1s and C 1s were recorded for silica–alumina samples. The Pt 4f level was recorded but this energy region was overshadowed by the presence of a very strong Al 2p peak, thus, for these samples, the Pt 4d and Al 2s lines were also analyzed. Pt 4d and Al 2s lines were used for quantification, but it is too broad to study the platinum chemical environment and Pt 4f was used for this purpose. On Ti–Si based solids the binding energies of Si 2p, Ti 2p, Na 1s, K 2p, Pt 4f, O 1s and C 1s were recorded. The Pt 4f XPS spectra from the prepared catalysts are shown in Fig. 4, while numeric values of the binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 are reported in Table 4. For all catalysts the Pt 4f signal showed three components, the main one at 71.0eV can be clearly assigned to Pt0 [38]. The second component on all the catalysts appears at higher binding energies (71.8–72.0eV) and is more difficult to assign, because it could indicate the presence of Pt2+ on the surface [39] but could also be due to metallic Pt particles of 1–2nm [28]. Since all catalysts were calcined and reduced ex situ before XPS analysis and therefore exposed to atmospheric conditions during handling, the presence of Pt2+ could not be ruled out; these platinum species would be associated to oxide particles, since Pt in exchange positions is expected to show higher binding energies [28]. On the other hand, small metallic particles could be produced by the reduction of platinum in exchange sites [38]. The last component would be associated to Pt2+ at exchange sites of the zeolite [40]. Regarding XPS determined compositions (Table 4), for the MFI support (before ion-exchange) the Na/Si ratio (not shown) was 0.034 while for the Pt–MFI catalysts no Na could be detected by XPS, indicating a high degree of ion-exchange for this solid. This is also in agreement with the Pt/Si ratio shown in Table 4, which is almost the same as the Al/Si ratio measured by XPS. A high degree of exchange was also found for the MOR catalyst, where looking at the initial Al/Si ratio and to the M/Si and Pt/Si ratios after ion-exchange it can be estimated that exchange took place at over 70% of the sites. For the other solids the exchange achieved was lower as shown by the high M/Si ratios remaining after exchange. In spite of this, the highest value of the Pt/Si ratio (Pt/Si=0.098) was found for the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst. However, it must be remembered that this Pt is largely present outside the ETS-10 structure, as indicated by the XRD (Fig. 1) and hydrogen chemisorption (Table 3) measurements. Nevertheless, good results in terms of activity have been reported [2] in the SELOX reaction for other catalysts (Pt/LTA) with the metal outside the microporous structure. Finally, the Pt–FAU catalyst presents a different picture, in which while the degree of exchange is relatively low (around 16%, if we estimate it using the surface Pt/Si ratio) but the Pt seems to be mostly at exchange sites, as indicated by high dispersion of the metal (Table 3). 3.2 Activity tests 3.2.1 CO oxidation reaction in H2O-free streams. Effect of temperature and O2 partial pressure The evolution of CO conversion and selectivity with temperature at a fixed value of oxygen partial pressure (λ =2) for the different catalysts is shown in Fig. 5 . As can be seen, the highest activities correspond to the Pt–FAU and Pt–ETS-10 catalysts, although Pt–FAU is the only one that allows complete conversion of CO under these conditions. For the other catalysts, the undesired oxidation of H2 consumes the available oxygen and prevents complete conversion of CO. In contrast, Pt–FAU gives total conversion of CO at 453K, in spite of having a lower Pt load compared to Pt–ETS-10 and Pt–MOR. The high activity of this catalyst can be explained as a consequence of the higher dispersion of the metal in Pt–FAU, and also of the larger pore size and pore volume of this catalyst, but also of its higher selectivity, meaning that oxygen is consumed mainly in the oxidation of CO and therefore there is enough oxygen for full conversion. The rest of the work deals with Pt–FAU and Pt–ETS-10, where the best reaction results at λ =2 were obtained. The CO conversion and selectivity for different oxygen concentrations is presented as a function of temperature for the Pt–ETS-10 and Pt–FAU catalysts in Fig. 6 . As could be expected, the highest selectivities are reached for λ =1, but operating at the stoichiometric oxygen concentration does not allow full conversion, since part of the oxygen is consumed in H2 oxidation. As λ increases, both the selectivity and the temperature required to achieve a given CO conversion decrease for both catalysts. At any value of λ the selectivity is higher for the Pt–FAU catalyst, and because of this more efficient use of oxygen, the conversion reached is also generally higher, except for the cases where a large excess of oxygen is used (at λ =3 and 4), where somewhat larger conversions can be achieved with the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst. The minimum λ values for complete CO conversion are 2 for Pt–FAU and 3 for Pt–ETS-10. The TOF (turnover frequency) for both catalysts is presented in Fig. 7 , both per mol of Pt atoms and per mol of exposed Pt atoms. It can be seen that, in absolute terms, the TOF for Pt–FAU is clearly higher than for Pt–ETS-10 (roughly twice at 453K, Fig. 7a). However, the situation is reversed if we calculate the TOF per exposed Pt atom. In this case (Fig. 7b), the TOF of Pt–ETS-10 is much higher (roughly 5 times higher) than that of Pt–FAU. This higher intrinsic activity of the exposed atoms in catalysts with a low dispersion has been reported previously [41,42], and is related to the increase in the coordination number of Pt as dispersion decreases. Wolf and coworkers [41] showed that as the Pt crystallite size increases from 14 to 38Å the fraction of atoms in planar surfaces increases from 12.5% to over 60%, and estimated that the rate of CO oxidation on planar-surface atoms was at least 10 times higher than that on low coordination sites. 3.2.2 Effect of CO2 and H2O in SELOX activity The influence of H2O and CO2 on the SELOX catalysts has been widely studied [3,6,13,16,42], since these molecules are often present in the reactor feed. The main concern is the adsorption of these species on the active centers, inhibiting the catalyst activity. The adsorption behavior can be strongly modified depending on the nature of the support used. In this work, the effect of different feed compositions has been studied using the different reformate streams in Table 2. Figs. 7 and 8 analyze the influence of the support by comparing the behavior obtained with Pt–FAU and Pt–ETS-10, respectively. The results show that the nature of the support is indeed relevant in relation to the influence of CO2 and H2O on the catalyst performance. Thus, for Pt–FAU (Fig. 8) the influence of CO2 on the catalyst activity (comparison between reformate streams 1 and 2) seems to be negligible, while for Pt–ETS-10 (Fig. 9 ) a strong inhibition can be observed (e.g. at 433K the introduction of CO2 decreases the conversion from about 80% to 30%). This can be explained by taking into account the basic nature of ETS-10 [43], that gives rise to a strong interaction with CO2, a reactant of acid nature. In contrast, when Pt is supported on acid solids such as FAU, its activity is almost unaffected by CO2. It is interesting to note that the selectivity of the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst in the absence of CO2 also increases in spite of a higher conversion, a reversal of the usual selectivity–conversion tradeoff. This is more clearly appreciated in the selectivity–conversion plot of Fig. 9, where the comparison of feeds 1 and 2 shows that at any conversion the reaction selectivity is much lower in the presence of CO2. This would indicate some degree of selective poisoning by CO2 of the sites that are more active for CO oxidation. A similar, if less pronounced effect, is observed for the case of Pt–FAU in Fig. 8: while the activity for a given temperature is virtually the same with and without CO2 present in the feed, the selectivity for any given conversion is 10–20% higher when the feed does not contain CO2, again indicating a preferential effect of CO2 on selective oxidation sites. On the other hand, the addition of H2O has a clear positive effect on the activity of both catalysts, as can be inferred from the comparison of the curves corresponding to reformate streams 2 and 3 in Figs. 7 and 8. Thus, for the Pt–FAU catalyst (Fig. 8) the temperatures required for 50% and 100% CO conversion (T 50 and T 100) are reduced by 20K and 15K, respectively. For Pt–ETS-10 (Fig. 9) the effect is even larger: T 50 decreases by ca. 65K, and in the presence of water (reformate stream 3) a 100% conversion is reached at 433K. Even more remarkable, the selectivity remains nearly constant, in spite of a conversion increase from 40% to 100% as the temperature increases from 373K to 433K. Given the strong effect of water on the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst, a fourth series of experiments was carried out with this solid using a feed stream with water and without CO2 (reformate 4). Fig. 9 shows that the conversion and selectivity behavior of reformate feed stream 3 (with CO2 and H2O) is reproduced with feed stream 4. This means that the beneficial effect of water on this catalyst are similar, irrespective of the presence of CO2. Several authors have proposed an enhancement of the CO oxidation rate in the presence of steam [16,44,45]. Manasilp and Gulari [16] also found a strong increase in the activity of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts in the SELOX reaction in the presence of water (apparent activation energies reduced from 74kJ/mol to 37kJ/mol), and they discussed several reasons for this effect, namely, enhancement of the WGS reaction, modification of the ratio of Pt0 to Pt(O) x sites in the presence of water vapour, and formation of oxidant hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface. They attributed the observed increase of activity to the hydroxyl groups formed by the dissociative adsorption of H2O on Pt. Similar observations have been made by Yan et al. [46] who investigated CO oxidation over a Pt–Co/Al2O3 catalyst. An interesting mechanism for the influence of OH− groups on a Pt/SnO x catalyzed CO oxidation reaction has also been suggested by Schryer et al. [47] where modification of the Pt0 and Pt(O) x sites takes place. They proposed that OH− groups on the surface of a Pt/SnO2 catalyst participate in the oxidation of CO chemisorbed on adjacent Pt sites. Similar effects could also be at work in our catalysts, since XPS analyzes on the used Pt/ETS-10 catalysts confirmed the change of the Pt0/Pt(O) x ratio (Table 4). In addition, the surface modifications induced by water are likely to represent a major contribution to the remarkable effects observed, by which the presence of water is able to overcome the detrimental effects of CO2. In this respect are relevant the results obtained by Doskocil [48], who used ETS-10 to catalyze the addition of CO2 to propylene oxide and found that water favored the formation of surface OH groups, which enhanced the Bronsted acidity of the ETS-10. In our case, such an effect would help to compensate the strong inhibition effect of CO2 attributed to the basicity of the support. The effect of the presence of H2O in the reaction atmosphere was further studied in transient experiments with the catalyst Pt–ETS-10, using reformate streams 2 (with added CO2), and 3 (with added CO2 and H2O). To this end, the temperature was increased stepwise from 363K to 438K and at every temperature plateau streams 2 and 3 were successively introduced. Stabilization periods of ca. 1.5h were allowed before changing the feed to a different composition. Fig. 10 shows that at every temperature, the catalyst undergoes a sudden increase of activity following the change from reformate 2 (containing CO2) to reformate 3 (containing CO2 and H2O). As soon as water is removed from the feed the activity starts decreasing to a new lower level. This is consistent with the above hypothesis by which water would rapidly form hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, with the associated increase of activity [16] and at the same time increases the Brönsted acidity of the surface, reversing the adsorption of CO2. It is also interesting to note that the beneficial effects of the changes produced by water are noticeable for a long time after removing water from the feed. This can be seen in Fig. 10, where the conversion values are still clearly above their previous levels even after 2h under reformate 2 feed, suggesting the survival of a significant fraction of surface hydroxyl groups (Fig. 11 ). 3.2.3 Long term stability tests The stability of the Pt–FAU and Pt–ETS-10 catalysts was studied in longer term experiments, using reformate stream 3 (containing both CO2 and H2O) as feed. Fig. 10a and b shows the results obtained at two different temperatures for the Pt–FAU catalyst. It can be seen that both conversion and selectivity remain constant for over 180h on stream, with no apparent signs of deactivation. This is consistent with the good stability expected for Pt crystallites inside the FAU cages, and also with the lower sensitivity of this catalyst to poisoning by CO2 shown in the experiments with different feed compositions. In contrast, for the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst (tested here at an intermediate temperature) deactivation is apparent after about 55h of operation, affecting both the conversion and the selectivity of the SELOX reaction. Interestingly, the deactivation of the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst is reversible, and the catalyst activity and selectivity could be recovered by keeping the catalyst at 473K under nitrogen for 10h (results not shown). Given the temperatures involved, sintering can be discarded with almost certainty as a cause of deactivation. This was confirmed by XRD analysis (results not shown) that yielded the same crystallite size for fresh and used catalysts. The formation of carbon deposits also seems unlikely under the reaction conditions employed. Ruling out deactivation by sintering and coking is also consistent with the easy reactivation of the catalyst by a mild thermal treatment with N2 at 473K, strongly suggesting the removal of an adsorbed compound. Thus, reversible poisoning by CO2 is likely to be the cause of the observed deactivation. 4 Conclusions Pt–FAU and Pt–ETS-10 catalysts are active and selective for the SELOX oxidation of CO in H2 streams, when CO2 and/or H2O are also present in the reaction atmosphere. It is possible to obtain a high Pt load on both catalysts, although the dispersion is considerably higher on Pt–FAU, due to the higher concentration of exchange sites and to the more favorable porous structure. This higher Pt load is somewhat compensated in terms of catalytic activity, by a higher turnover frequency per exposed Pt atom in the case of Pt–ETS-10. The introduction of CO2 in the reactor feed does not seem to affect the activity of the Pt–FAU catalyst and has only a small effect on its selectivity. In contrast, CO2 strongly inhibits the activity of the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst, and also causes a large decrease in its selectivity. This can be related to the basicity of the ETS-10 support, which enhances interaction with CO2, while the extent of this interaction is lessened for the acid FAU solid. The introduction of water in the reactor feed is positive for both catalysts, but its effect is dramatic for Pt–ETS-10, where the inhibition by CO2 is completely reversed. This is probably due to a combined effect of the formation of oxidant hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface and the reduction of the basicity of the support upon the introduction of water. In any case, in real fuel processing systems the water concentration in the feed is likely to be considerably higher than that used here (2.9%), and therefore further studies are needed to confirm the positive effects of water when higher concentration levels are used. Finally, CO2 is also the likely responsible for the deactivation that appears in the Pt–ETS-10 catalyst after some 50h on stream. However the catalytic activity can be regained by a mild treatment under nitrogen at 473K. Acknowledgments Financial support from MICINN, Spain, is gratefully acknowledged. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of CO in the presence of H2O and CO2 has been studied on Pt supported on different zeolitic materials (MOR, ZSM-5, FAU and ETS-10) using a range of operating conditions and a variety of characterization techniques. The behavior of the Pt–ETS-10 and Pt–FAU catalysts has been investigated in more depth and the results obtained have been compared and related to the different characteristics of the supports. The best results in the presence of H2O and CO2 were obtained with Pt–FAU catalysts, showing stable catalytic activity and complete conversion of CO (λ =2) at 439K.
coredata.dc:title: Selective oxidation of CO in the presence of H2, CO2 and H2O, on different zeolite-supported Pt catalysts
